question_text: This question is about waves in the electromagnetic (e-m) spectrum. Draw one straight line from each type of e-m radiation to its use. One line has been drawn for you. Figure 1 shows some types of radiation that form part of the e-m spectrum and some uses of e-m radiation.
subject: Physics

question_text: This question is about waves in the electromagnetic (e-m) spectrum. Which of these waves has the highest frequency? A infrared B microwaves C ultraviolet D visible light
subject: Physics

question_text: X-rays are also part of the e-m spectrum. Figure 2 shows an airport security scanner using X-rays to scan passengers’ bags. Explain why X-rays are used to scan passengers’ bags.
subject: Physics

question_text: X-rays are also part of the e-m spectrum. Figure 2 shows an airport security scanner using X-rays to scan passengers’ bags. Explain why passengers are not scanned with X-rays.
subject: Physics

question_text: Figure 3 shows a ray of light striking a mirror. The angle of incidence is 30˚ and the ray of light is reflected. The angle of reflection is the angle between A the mirror and the incident ray B the mirror and the normal C the reflected ray and the incident ray D the reflected ray and the normal

question_text: Figure 4 shows two lenses, P and Q, arranged to form a simple telescope. State one use for a telescope.

question_text: In a swimming pool, a wave is produced with a wavelength of 4.0 m and a velocity of 0.8 m/s. Calculate the frequency of the wave. State the unit of frequency. Use the equation v = f × λ frequency of wave .............................................................. unit
subject: Physics

question_text: Figure 9 shows a metal cube filled with hot water. Four sides of the cube have different surfaces, as shown in Figure 9. The thermal energy radiated by each side of the box is measured using a thermal energy detector connected to a millivoltmeter. The detector is moved to get a reading of the thermal energy emitted from each side of the box. Suggest a possible millivoltmeter reading for the shiny black surface.
subject: Physics

question_text: Figure 9 shows a metal cube filled with hot water. Four sides of the cube have different surfaces, as shown in Figure 9. subject: Physics

subject: Physics

subject: Physics

question_text: In the UK, electricity is generated using non-renewable and renewable energy resources. The graph in Figure 18 shows how the amount of electricity generated by these resources changed from 2012 to 2020. Explain how and why the amount of electricity generated by renewable and non-renewable energy resources has changed from 2012 to 2020. Your answer should include the trends shown in Figure 18, the change in the amount of electricity generated by at least one renewable resource, and the change in the amount of electricity generated by at least one non-renewable resource.
subject: Physics

question_text: Figure 19 shows two objects, E and D. E emits a sound. D detects the sound. E is moving in the direction shown by the arrow, but D is not moving. E emits a sound of wavelength 1.86 m. D measures the wavelength of this sound as 1.98 m. Calculate the difference between the wavelength that E emits and the wavelength that D detects. difference in wavelength = ..............................................................
subject: Physics

question_text: Figure 19 shows two objects, E and D. E emits a sound. D detects the sound. E is moving in the direction shown by the arrow, but D is not moving. E emits a sound of wavelength 1.86 m. D measures the wavelength of this sound as 1.98 m. The velocity of sound is 330 m / s. Calculate the velocity of E using the equation: velocity of E = velocity of sound × (difference in wavelength / wavelength emitted by E). velocity of E = ..............................................................
subject: Physics

question_text: The wavelength of light emitted from distant galaxies is different when the light is detected on Earth. Explain how this difference in wavelength shows that the Universe is expanding.
subject: Physics
